instruction: [INST] Analyze this file to learn MacBook motherboard repair. The 'definitions' section explains key technical terms. The 'threads' section contains real-world repair discussions. Use both sections to understand and learn how to troubleshoot MacBook issues. Posts from username 'larossmann' , 'dukefawks' , and '2informaticos' are posts from trusted experts.[/INST]

definitions.820-3536: What is 820-3536? a LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER.
definitions.PPBUS_G3H: What is PPBUS_G3H? Main system power rail that charges the battery, or is power from the battery, that everything else is powered from. .

threads.title: <LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>820-3536</LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER> <SIGNAL>PPBUS_S5_HS_COMPUTING</SIGNAL> is shorted
threads.message:
Hi guys, I am not expert in Mac repair. Please help me find the solution.
Macbook came with some corrosion water. No power no fan green then orange cable when the charger is plugged. 
PPBUS-S5-HS-COMPYTING is shorted ground. As I attached under <TRANSISTOR>Q7630</TRANSISTOR> there is a problem. 
I took these components to see if I could find the shorted part.
<CAPACITOR>C7622</CAPACITOR>
<CAPACITOR>C7624</CAPACITOR>
<RESISTOR>R7202</RESISTOR>
<RESISTOR>R5400</RESISTOR>
<TRANSISTOR>Q7430</TRANSISTOR>
<TRANSISTOR>Q7630</TRANSISTOR>
<TRANSISTOR>Q7310</TRANSISTOR>
<CAPACITOR>C7619</CAPACITOR>
l7630
But no lock still shorted. Except that area that I attached components seems fine without any issue or water damaging under the microscope.

threads.title: <LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>820-3536</LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER> <SIGNAL>PPBUS_S5_HS_COMPUTING</SIGNAL> is shorted
threads.message:
First of all, welcome to the forum!

Post the exact ohm resistance of that short.
Compare with all big coils to ground.

threads.title: <LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>820-3536</LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER> <SIGNAL>PPBUS_S5_HS_COMPUTING</SIGNAL> is shorted
threads.message:
Thanks.
I didn't get, sorry. You mean I took off the components again from the board then measure the ohm.
Could you please explain more?

threads.title: <LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>820-3536</LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER> <SIGNAL>PPBUS_S5_HS_COMPUTING</SIGNAL> is shorted
threads.message:
You've said to have short to ground.
0 ohm, 10 ohm, how much???
Compare that value with resistance to ground on all big coils.
No need to remove anything (yet).

threads.title: <LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>820-3536</LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER> <SIGNAL>PPBUS_S5_HS_COMPUTING</SIGNAL> is shorted
threads.message: It shows 0.03 ohm compare to other big coils It is same amount.0.02 or 0.03

threads.title: <LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>820-3536</LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER> <SIGNAL>PPBUS_S5_HS_COMPUTING</SIGNAL> is shorted
threads.message: Bad news. I found ppbus-g3h and ppvbat g3h chgr reg is also shorted. :cautious:

threads.title: <LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>820-3536</LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER> <SIGNAL>PPBUS_S5_HS_COMPUTING</SIGNAL> is shorted
threads.message:
I hope you've disconnected power from the board, before measuring in diode mode.
In fact allow 10-15s, to discharge any remanent voltage.

I was talking to compare with ohm resistance to ground on big coils.
You cannot get 0 ohm on all of them...

I specified OHM value, not diode mode.
I doubt you can get 0.03 ohm, nor even in ohm scale; multimeter probes give aprox 0.3 ohm already.

threads.title: <LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>820-3536</LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER> <SIGNAL>PPBUS_S5_HS_COMPUTING</SIGNAL> is shorted
threads.message:
No, the power was disconnected. I was just testing board without connecting to power.
I know I look stupid and very amateur but really want to solve it. Yes I tested on diode mode yesterday.
Could you please tell me in which range ohm of multimeters should I test?
Also, I found out PPBUS-GH3 and PPVBAT-GH3-CHRG-REG were shorted as well. After I took F7140 off of board, the other way which is PPVBAT-GH3-CHRG-REG returned to normal and not shorted. So still PPBUS-GH3 and <SIGNAL>PPBUS_S5_HS_COMPUTING</SIGNAL> are shorted to ground.

threads.title: <LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>820-3536</LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER> <SIGNAL>PPBUS_S5_HS_COMPUTING</SIGNAL> is shorted
threads.message:
Actual multimeters are all auto-range.
If not, choose 200 ohm scale.

threads.title: <LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>820-3536</LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER> <SIGNAL>PPBUS_S5_HS_COMPUTING</SIGNAL> is shorted
threads.message:
Most of the big coils are shorted for example:
<CAPACITOR>C7543</CAPACITOR>
<CAPACITOR>C7540</CAPACITOR>
<CAPACITOR>C7542</CAPACITOR>
<CAPACITOR>C7580</CAPACITOR>
<CAPACITOR>C7314</CAPACITOR>
<CAPACITOR>C7313</CAPACITOR>
<CAPACITOR>C7324</CAPACITOR>
I can not compare because all are shorted. I get 1.8 ohm on all of them. Only one <CAPACITOR>C1031</CAPACITOR> I get 63.1 ohm
I confused.

threads.title: <LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>820-3536</LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER> <SIGNAL>PPBUS_S5_HS_COMPUTING</SIGNAL> is shorted
threads.message:
Update
I took off these components to check the board. L7130  I have shorted ground on pin2 of l7130. Also, <RESISTOR>R7150</RESISTOR> only pin2 is shorted. F7700 PIN1 is shorted , pin2 is normal.
Am I wasting time with this way of testing?

threads.title: <LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>820-3536</LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER> <SIGNAL>PPBUS_S5_HS_COMPUTING</SIGNAL> is shorted
threads.message:
You waste time if you do not want to post short values, as already asked.
If you only mention several components connected to the same rail, what you see intersting?

You can consider short some low values, as 5-20 ohms, which can be good values, depending where you measured.
Is IMPOSSIBLE to get short on all big coils to ground!!!

Can you post again accurate ohm value to ground measured at <SIGNAL>PPBUS_G3H</SIGNAL>?
<RESISTOR>R5400</RESISTOR> is an easy to access test point.

Then post EXACT resistance to ground at L7310/20, L7430, etc .

threads.title: <LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>820-3536</LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER> <SIGNAL>PPBUS_S5_HS_COMPUTING</SIGNAL> is shorted
threads.message:
<RESISTOR>R5400</RESISTOR> all pins shows 1.9-2.1 ohm.
L7310: 59.5 OHM
L7320: 59.5 OHM
<RESISTOR>R5510</RESISTOR>: 270 OHM
<RESISTOR>R7310</RESISTOR>/<RESISTOR>R7320</RESISTOR>: 65 OHM
<CAPACITOR>C7440</CAPACITOR>/1/2   L7430 : 270 OHM
L7520 :1270 OHM
L7560: 7.76k on 20K OHM
<CAPACITOR>C4696</CAPACITOR>/<CAPACITOR>C3387</CAPACITOR>/<CAPACITOR>C3287</CAPACITOR> 7.7 K OHM not fixed range.

and ground pin on others like <CAPACITOR>C7740</CAPACITOR>/1/2 is 0.08 ohm
Thanks for following

threads.title: <LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>820-3536</LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER> <SIGNAL>PPBUS_S5_HS_COMPUTING</SIGNAL> is shorted
threads.message:
"and ground pin on others"
Do you mean that you'ne measured ground to ground???
Be serious man.
Do not post more than we need here...

If no big coil has the same resistance to ground like <SIGNAL>PPBUS_G3H</SIGNAL>, then you are safe to inject voltage.
Start injecting with 1V and slowly go uo, if needed (at <RESISTOR>R5400</RESISTOR>, for example).
Set first amp limit to max on your lab PSU.
Then check with your fingers where the board heats.
Should be some cpacitor shorted, on <SIGNAL>PPBUS_G3H</SIGNAL> power rail.

threads.title: <LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>820-3536</LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER> <SIGNAL>PPBUS_S5_HS_COMPUTING</SIGNAL> is shorted
threads.message: I connected the power as you told me to the battery connector also <RESISTOR>R5400</RESISTOR> from 1v to 2.5v. The only part got heat <TRANSISTOR>Q7630</TRANSISTOR> under the IC a layer of the board was pilled off I took it with cutter. See the picture. Also, <CAPACITOR>C7619</CAPACITOR> I took it off. But the place under <TRANSISTOR>Q7630</TRANSISTOR> when I connect to power is burning smoking. Nothing gets hot on <SIGNAL>PPBUS_G3H</SIGNAL> power rail.

threads.title: <LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>820-3536</LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER> <SIGNAL>PPBUS_S5_HS_COMPUTING</SIGNAL> is shorted
threads.message:
You've probably fried the board now.

I don't really understand what you did.
I said to conect lab PSU to <RESISTOR>R5400</RESISTOR>; starting with 1V.
Who said something about battery connector???

Don't tell me thay you powered up the board with battery (or charger) and also inject voltage with lab PSU to <RESISTOR>R5400</RESISTOR>.

You didn't report any short to ground at L7630 before.
Probably killed the CPU now...

threads.title: <LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>820-3536</LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER> <SIGNAL>PPBUS_S5_HS_COMPUTING</SIGNAL> is shorted
threads.message:
I understand. Check my first post I reported <SIGNAL>PPBUS_S5_HS_COMPUTING</SIGNAL> rail is shorted. Also I reported L7630 is shorted. 
At the first view when I saw the motherboard found out the <TRANSISTOR>Q7630</TRANSISTOR> was defective. I posted the picture first post. Under the IC a top layer was ripped and was peeled off half.
I connected positive hub of power supply to <RESISTOR>R5400</RESISTOR> and negative hub to ground started 1v then went to 2v same area started smoking.

threads.title: <LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>820-3536</LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER> <SIGNAL>PPBUS_S5_HS_COMPUTING</SIGNAL> is shorted
threads.message:
I asked you several times to post exact ohm value of that short.
In the first post you mentioned lot of components, but didn't post exact values.

I asked lot of rimes to compare short value on <SIGNAL>PPBUS_G3H</SIGNAL> with ALL big coils; never got an exact reply.
If <TRANSISTOR>Q7630</TRANSISTOR> was the reason for shorting <SIGNAL>PPBUS_G3H</SIGNAL> to L7630, then I didn't expect to still have short on <SIGNAL>PPBUS_G3H</SIGNAL>, once <TRANSISTOR>Q7630</TRANSISTOR> was removed.
Unless you have a short between copper layers, under <TRANSISTOR>Q7630</TRANSISTOR>.
And that is a big problem; not sure if you can properly clean that area and resolder the MOSFET correctly.

However, if you lift L7630 and get short to ground on its pad 2 (<RESISTOR>R7640</RESISTOR>), then CPU is dead; do not waste more time on this board.

threads.title: <LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>820-3536</LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER> <SIGNAL>PPBUS_S5_HS_COMPUTING</SIGNAL> is shorted
threads.message:
Sorry for delay here was holiday.
Yes you are right. I had a shorted ground under <TRANSISTOR>Q7630</TRANSISTOR>. I shaved the surface then short gone. So I don't have shorted on PPBUS-G3H and PPBUS-S5-HS-COMPUTING anymore but yes I have short under l7630 pin2 and <RESISTOR>R7640</RESISTOR> pin1.
I am a cellphone technician recently I am trying to learn and fix computers as well, so I am an amateur. Thanks for helping me.
